properties.text: Index:
To get it, you'll need white petals, cobblestone, water, and seeds, none of which are easily available in the Nether.
One of the more important tools you'll need to survive in the Nether will likely be the Pure Daisy.
Mining in the Nether
Coal

You can find most any ore you'll want in the Nether. In fact, you might find that the ores are very abundant there!

That being said, nearly everything in the Nether wants to kill you. The ores you'll find there are likely going to be in precarious locations. The ores might be located in geodes filled with hazardous fluids. Or, the ore itself might try to kill you, in Tiberium's case.
Coal deposits are found suspended in open areas of the Nether. Take some caution mining it: some of the coal is on fire.
Geodes
Inside, however, you'll find a thin layer of ore, such as iron, like in the image below.
Many ores, such as iron, are found inside of geodes. The geodes often give little hint as to what they contain, being a featureless black blob like in the image above.
Be extremely careful cracking open these geodes! Some are filled with hazardous fluids such as lava, quicksand, and pyrotheum.
The Lava Sea

Some ores, especially some of the more useful ores, are only found specifically under the lava. This includes dimensional shards, uranium, and redstone.

Fortunately, there are relatively easy ways to protect yourself from the heat of lava. Fire protection potions might be the obvious route, but dried magma slime also works very well, if for a shorter duration.
Food is, unsurprisingly, scarce in the Nether. However, it is not impossible to find.
Foraging in the Nether
Valus Omniferum
Valus Omniferum is a red vine that grows a white melon-like fruit. These valus melons can be cooked into a bread-like substance that is surprisingly nutritious.
These seeds can be planted on tilled nether dirt that has a lava source nearby (within 2 meters). Nether dirt can be made by combining dirt with soul sand or it can simply be found in the Nether.
Valus omniferum can be farmed. To do so, you'll have to extract the seeds from the melons.

Furthermore, valus omniferum stalks can be harvested from the fully grown plant, which grows as tall as four meters. Valus stalks can be turned into fibers that can be made into either paper or string.
Ovis Atre, or the nether sheep, is a type of livestock that dwells in the Nether. Like many of the local denizens, they can be very aggressive, but will not attack unless provoked.

Nether sheep can be butchered for their mutton. The mutton is quite edible, but the act of butchering an ovis atre will likely provoke the others in the vicinity to attack you.

In addition, like their overworld counterparts, nether sheep grow a thick coat of wool. This can be harvested with shears. Nether sheep will regrow their wool after consuming equisetum cineris, or nether grass (also affectionately called "murder grass").

Speaking of equisetum cineris, the roots of this grass are edible. If you carefully pull up the grass with the assistance of a pair of shears, you'll not only collect cineris fibers, but you'll also collect the roots, which can be replanted or consumed. The fibers can be used to make tools, especially those made of quartz. 

Furthermore, the stubborn nature of the grass will allow the original tuft to regrow, making it an easily renewable resource. This grass grows almost anywhere and on anything.

Hell Cows are a highly aggressive, intelligent cow that dwells in the Nether. There is some question as to the moral implications to consuming an intelligent creature, but there is no doubt that their flesh has a very similar taste to their overworld counterparts.

Beware their halberds, as they have a rather long reach.

Hell cows tend to search for and horde gems. There is a small chance that they'll have one.

Sinuous weeds are plants that grow very close to lava. It is a very dangerous plant that tends to throw creatures near it into the lava it grows near.

A fully grown sinuous weed can be chopped down to collect sinuous fibers and sinuous spores, which are edible and have a few other uses. Like equisetum cineris, sinuous weed is a tenacious plant, tending to regrow even after being chopped down.

Sinuous resin, made from cooking sinuous spores, can act as a substitute for purple dye or slime.
If you are truly desperate, zombie pigmen's rotten flesh can be consumed. It may be wise to dry the flesh on a drying rack before consumption, though, to prevent food poisoning.

Magma slime islands, an orange-colored island with similarly colored slime trees, are abundant with, unsurprisingly, magma slime. They also tend to have coagulated blood. Once again, the drying rack will come in handy, as you can dry this slime into a very edible and useful slime drop.
